Application_Facts: Zhang was absent from Canada for significant periods due to her husband's employment in Japan; citizenship judge considered passive connections and failed to assess relevant facts such as family ties outside Canada
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet three years of physical residence in Canada during the four years preceding application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to properly apply the qualitative test for residence
Evidence_Used: Periods of absence from Canada, family ties abroad, nature of connections to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess factual basis for residency, including external family ties
Decision_Outcome: Federal Court allowed the appeal, set aside the citizenship judge's decision
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Setting aside of the grant of citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Qualitative test for residence under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not meet statutory residency requirement; improper consideration of passive connections instead of actual physical presence and relevant factual circumstances

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence
Application_Facts: Applicant Dedaj was short of required physical presence days but had established ties to Canada
Residency_Compliance: Incomplete physical presence; qualitative factors not assessed
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to apply the qualitative test for residency
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis regarding applicant's Canadian ties during relevant period
Decision_Outcome: Original application dismissed due to insufficient physical presence days
Remedy_Sought: Remand for reassessment by another citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Both physical presence and qualitative residency tests under the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Legal error occurred by omitting the qualitative assessment of residency despite potential ties to Canada
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via citizenship judge), Federal Court on review

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Koo was physically present in Canada for only 232 days within the four-year period preceding his application; maintained business interests in Hong Kong; made frequent visits to Canada but did not establish it as his primary residence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a decision of a Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence, travel history, ties to Hong Kong, nature and frequency of visits to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of established residence in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years (1095 days) of accumulated residence in Canada within four years prior to application under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Koo did not meet the statutory residency requirement; Canada was not his primary residence; temporary visits insufficient to satisfy residency obligation

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 551 days over four years, retained business interests in Colombia, and traveled frequently.
Procedural_Issue: Appeal under s. 14(5) of Citizenship Act and s. 21 of Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Used: Physical presence records, business ties in Colombia, travel history, Koo factors assessment
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship judge found stronger connection to Colombia
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Centralization of mode of existence, Koo factors
Decision_Rationale: Frequent absences and significant ties to Colombia indicated that the applicant had not centralized their life in Canada.

Application_Facts: El Ocla was physically present in Canada for 996 days, falling short of the 1095-day requirement, but had established strong ties to Canada as a tenured professor.
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient physical presence; qualitative factors not considered
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to consider the qualitative residency test
Evidence_Used: Proof of employment, tenure as a professor, and establishment of life in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Qualitative evidence of residency was disregarded
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship application decision
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by another citizenship judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Qualitative residency test under Re Koo and s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge erred by applying only the physical presence test and failing to consider whether El Ocla had centralized his mode of living in Canada under the qualitative test.
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via citizenship judge), Federal Court on appeal

Application_Facts: Hao was absent from Canada for prolonged periods, accumulating only 972 days of presence out of the required 1095 days within four years preceding her application.
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judge's decision to the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, travel history to China
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or justification for absences
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-year physical presence requirement in Canada within four years prior to application
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the physical presence test; Hao’s frequent travels to China prevented compliance with residency requirements.

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence in Canada during the four years preceding the application while studying abroad
Residency_Compliance: No, failed to accumulate 1,095 days of physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal reviewed and dismissed by Federal Court Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required residency duration
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of residence within four years prior to application under Section 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Appellant did not meet statutory residency requirement due to prolonged absence from Canada for studies

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Respondent misrepresented residency and whether the Citizenship Judge's decision was reasonable
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reevaluation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's statements about absences were found to be false
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 29 of the Citizenship Act (false representation)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of number of days absent from Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancy between reported and actual absences (360 vs. 799 days)
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Physical presence as primary test for residency
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Actual duration of absences and lack of credible ties to Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision due to failure to address misrepresentation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False declaration of residency duration in application

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in granting citizenship despite misrepresentation and insufficient proof of residency
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Respondent provided inconsistent and false information on absences
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Self-reported residency data, official travel records
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 5(1)(c) and Section 29 of the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to meet three-year physical residency requirement and false reporting
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Actual absences totaled 799 days, far exceeding claimed 360 days
Crimes.Application_Error: Incorrect reporting of days spent outside Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Statutory residency requirement based on physical presence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Lack of documentation proving continuous residence and ties to Canada
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Submission of inaccurate residency information in citizenship application

Application_Facts: Gonzalez fled Colombia due to threats from FARC and claimed refugee status in Canada, which was initially denied.
Procedural_Issue: Board did not adequately consider evidence on effectiveness of state protection
Evidence_Used: Credibility findings, evidence on Colombia's protection programs for targeted individuals
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to properly assess the ineffectiveness of state protection in Colombia
Decision_Outcome: Initial denial of refugee claim by the Board
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, quashed the decision
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a protected person under refugee protection provisions
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by another member of the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether the applicant rebutted the presumption of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board erred in concluding applicant failed to rebut presumption of state protection despite evidence showing Colombia's protection programs were ineffective for targeted individuals
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequate consideration of factors in H&C application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence for abuse, credible risk, or hardship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence exceeding normal expectations

Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Pannu overstayed her visa and applied for H&C relief
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Used: Treatment as divorced woman in India
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Factors considered but not sufficient to meet threshold
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal error; decision within acceptable range

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of officer’s consideration in H&C refusal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Alleged ignored evidence not substantiated
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship upon return to home country

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with deportation order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Third H&C application following deportation order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Hardship not shown to be unusual or disproportionate
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer reasonably assessed claims
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from removal on H&C grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision rational and within bounds of reasonableness

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Officer’s consideration of H&C factors after work permit expiry
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims assessed but not sufficient for relief
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of evidence meeting H&C threshold

Application_Facts: Respondent was absent from Canada for 776 days over four years; maintained strong family, social, and financial ties to Canada; absences deemed temporary
Residency_Compliance: Partially non-compliant with physical presence but compliant under central mode of existence test
Evidence_Used: Family ties, social connections, financial ties in Canada, travel history
Credibility_Assessment: Respondent found credible; connections to Canada assessed as substantial
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application approved by citizenship judge
Relief_Sought: Minister sought cancellation of citizenship approval due to insufficient physical presence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for central mode of existence
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded that respondent centralized mode of existence in Canada despite absences

Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Violation_Type: Non-compliance with humanitarian and compassionate application requirements
Application_Facts: Ms. Jung had no family ties in Canada, limited financial stability, and alleged risk of abuse in Korea deemed comparable to general population risk
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to apply correct legal test for H&C grounds
Evidence_Used: Lack of familial and economic ties to Canada, assessment of conditions in Korea
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Credibility_Assessment: Risk of abuse not found credible or distinct from general societal conditions in Korea
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; no legal error found
Relief_Sought: Allowance of H&C application to remain in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship test under Section 25(1) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer exercised discretion reasonably within statutory framework; no error in law or fact

Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Application_Facts: Ms. Jung overstayed her visa, submitted two H&C applications, claimed fear of abuse in Korea
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to properly assess H&C grounds
Evidence_Used: Duration of overstay, lack of significant ties to Canada, country condition reports on Korea
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient demonstration of hardship or integration in Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Fear of abuse not substantiated as significantly different from general risks in Korea
Outcome: Judicial review denied; decision upheld as reasonable
Relief_Sought: Permission to remain in Canada on H&C grounds
Remedy_Sought: Certification of question of general importance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship under Section 25(1) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: Officer appropriately balanced factors and applied correct legal test; decision within permissible range

Violation_Type: Credibility assessment without considering corroborating evidence
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection and procedural fairness
Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law, particularly IRPA and the principles of procedural fairness in administrative decision-making
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution in Bangladesh due to political activities; submitted testimony, psychological report indicating PTSD, and letters supporting political involvement and police issues
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of testimony by the claimant, as determined by the Refugee Division
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all relevant evidence, including psychological and corroborating documents, before rejecting the claim
Evidence_Used: Personal testimony, psychological report on PTSD, letters supporting political involvement and police persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Panel did not address the psychological report or supporting letters in its decision
Credibility_Assessment: Panel dismissed claimant's testimony as fabricated without analyzing objective corroborating evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee Division rejected the applicants' claims based on credibility
Outcome: Federal Court allowed judicial review, found error in assessment
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Refugee Division’s decision
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of the refugee claim by a new panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in administrative law; obligation to consider all relevant evidence under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The panel failed to properly assess credibility by disregarding independent corroborating evidence, violating procedural fairness
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Violation_Type: Refugee claim based on lack of well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Sri Lanka due to Tamil ethnicity; Board found no credible evidence linking fear to race or political opinion; incidents involved authorities and post-war extortion unrelated to Convention grounds
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, linkage of evidence to Convention grounds
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, encounters with authorities, context of post-war Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence connecting experiences to race or political opinion
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's fear not credible or insufficiently linked to protected grounds
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the denial and granting of refugee protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Section 96
Decision_Rationale: No evidence established a link between the applicant's experiences and persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or social group; incidents were attributed to general law enforcement or criminal activity
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB), Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Sidhu spent only 26 days in Canada over a five-year period
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: No, only 26 days in Canada over 5 years
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: IAD failed to properly assess evidence and ignored inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence for claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in Sidhu's claims were not addressed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD allowed appeal on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court set aside IAD decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: IAD decision was unreasonable due to failure to consider all evidence and relevant factors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency obligations under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable grant of humanitarian and compassionate relief despite non-compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court set aside IAD decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Contradictory evidence about business and family situation not assessed
Evidence_Type: Claims of family obligations in India
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 28 and Section 67, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Minimal physical presence in Canada (26 days)
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Appeal before IAD, followed by judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Contradictory evidence regarding claimant's activities and residence in India
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family ties and hardship claimed but inadequately supported
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD granted relief; Federal Court remitted for redetermination

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and identity of the applicant
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found lacking credibility due to inconsistencies and implausibilities
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution upon return to North Korea
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroborative documentation
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under s. 72(1) of the Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Speculative findings and insufficient consideration of evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to prove identity and risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Corroborative evidence dismissed without sufficient basis
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation of identity and nationality documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Establishment of credible identity as a North Korean citizen
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 96 and 97
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in narrative and implausibilities in testimony
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, referred back for reconsideration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove identity and nationality
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Doubts about dialect expertise and authenticity of supporting letters
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must prove identity and nationality for refugee status
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Credible fear of persecution in North Korea
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed to be North Korean defector seeking protection
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Allowance of judicial review and referral for re-hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim involving credibility and entry method
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Speculative rejection of key evidence without proper justification
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Corroborative evidence submitted but inadequately assessed
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged smuggling involvement through irregular border crossing
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No explicit criminal record, but credibility concerns raised
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential misrepresentation and lack of verified identity
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Fear of persecution if returned to North Korea
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Board Member at Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Outcome: Reconsideration ordered by different Board member
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to properly assess evidence and reliance on speculation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Credibility undermining through false statements or omissions
Crimes.Governing_Law: Statutory interpretation and procedural fairness under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed North Korean origin but faced credibility challenges
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Entered Canada and made a refugee claim
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper discounting of affidavits and speculative assumptions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentary proof of nationality
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found inconsistent and implausible by Board
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, matter referred for reconsideration
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of negative refugee determination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Rehearing before a different decision maker

Application_Facts: Applicants' financial status, integration, and child's best interests were considered
Officer reviewed prior decisions and new evidence fairly
Procedural_Issue: H&C officer's assessment of evidence
Evaluation of factors
Potential bias concerns
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for H&C decisions
Correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: H&C decisions require reasonableness
Procedural fairness observed
Bias not substantiated

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in or instigating the subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: PKK uses force against Turkish government
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Armed attacks, supply support to PKK
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Providing supplies, participating in armed attacks
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Admissions by Suleyman supported by context
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Suleyman’s statements deemed credible due to consistency

Crimes.Crime_Name: Subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Application_Facts: Suleyman assisted PKK, present during armed attack
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – based on actual involvement
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over visa officer decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admissions accepted as truthful
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Certification of question and reversal of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Suleyman’s actions aligned with subversion by force
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, affirmed by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissible on security grounds for being a member of an organization that there are reasonable grounds to believe engages in subversion by force of any government
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Association with PKK poses national security risk
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Assisting PKK, including propaganda and attacks
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible and consistent admissions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Challenge to interpretation and procedure of inadmissibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in an organization engaging in subversion by force.
Crimes.Application_Facts: Suleyman admitted assisting PKK, involved in attacks
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of administrative decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Admissions treated as reliable
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Membership and active support meet statutory threshold
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer under IRPA, upheld by Federal Court

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's criminal history and alleged gang leadership raising public safety concerns in Canada versus risk of torture/persecution in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly reassess risks as per prior court order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on outdated evidence; ignored credible NGO and SLMM reports
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent weighing of evidence and sources
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Prevention of deportation due to risk of torture
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of risk and balancing exercise
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Flawed evidence treatment and improper balancing of danger to public vs. risk upon return

Crimes.Violation_Type: Deportation based on serious criminality despite refugee status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant’s history of serious criminality and gang involvement while being a Convention refugee
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to seriousness of criminal acts
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review following prior court-ordered reassessment
Evidence_Used: Corroborative evidence of targeting by authorities or LTTE
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored relevant NGO reports and failed to address corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evaluation of risk evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed and remanded for new assessment
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Halt deportation due to risk of cruel treatment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: New risk assessment and balancing under s. 97 and s. 115(2)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to reasonably assess risk of torture and balance against public danger

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to consider updated and credible evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Relevant reports were available but dismissed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable assessment of risk and evidence
Crimes.Criminal_Activity: Alleged gang leadership and organized criminal involvement
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: History of serious criminality and gang association
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Danger to the public and organized criminality
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Risk of targeting by Sri Lankan authorities or LTTE upon return
Crimes.Outcome: Decision quashed, case remanded for reassessment
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Flawed evaluation of evidence regarding risk in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Dismissal of corroborative and credible evidence without justification

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration sponsorship refusal based on non-disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of visa officer's decision to deny permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's spouse failed to disclose marriage prior to sponsor's permanent residency, affecting credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Marital status disclosure records, application forms, supporting documentation for humanitarian claims
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 117(9)(d), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission of prior marital status leading to inadmissibility under family class provisions
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to disclose marriage before sponsor obtained permanent resident status
Crimes.Application_Error: Non-disclosure of existing marriage in immigration application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under regulatory framework
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – officer considered all factors but found them insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Spouse not examined or accompanying at time of sponsor’s permanent residency grant
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal upheld; exception not granted on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No explicit fraud found, but misrepresentation via omission

Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-disclosure of material fact in sponsorship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 117(9)(d) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant’s spouse did not disclose marriage before sponsor became a permanent resident
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Sponsor obtained permanent residency without disclosing spouse
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inadvertent omission of marital status deemed non-compelling for exemption
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to include spouse during initial examination as part of sponsor’s application
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over immigration and refugee matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Marriage certificate, application forms, personal declarations
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of compelling evidence to justify humanitarian and compassionate relief
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Omission affected assessment of completeness and honesty in application
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn visa officer's decision through judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Humanitarian and compassionate factors did not outweigh regulatory bar under section 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Federal Court of Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act - Residency requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant accumulated only 137 days of physical presence in Canada; worked abroad for UNICEF; maintained property and family ties in Canada
Residency_Compliance: No - failed to accumulate 1,095 days of residence within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Appeal process under statutory framework
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, employment with UNICEF, property ownership, family connections in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to establish central mode of living in Canada despite prolonged absence
Outcome: Applicant remains ineligible for Canadian citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada within four years before application; exception for central mode of living
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, with deference to Citizenship Judge's expertise
Decision_Rationale: Extensive absences not justified under temporary absence or central mode of living exceptions; insufficient residential presence as required by law

Violation_Type: Failure to establish persecution or lack of state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections related to refugee protection
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Mexico as a homosexual, citing police harassment and societal discrimination
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Incidents described by applicant, country condition information
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence that incidents amounted to persecution or that state protection was unavailable
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on objective sufficiency of evidence
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of negative refugee determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Board found incidents isolated and not escalating; internal flight alternative and state protection available in Mexico

Application_Facts: Applicants' refugee claim denied based on presumed state protection without adequate analysis of personal risk evidence
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to address key evidence regarding Colombia’s inability to protect ELN-targeted individuals
No credibility findings made despite contradictory evidence
Evidence_Used: Expert evidence on country conditions in Colombia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider personal risk in context of country conditions
Omission of critical evidence on state protection capacity
Credibility_Assessment: No credibility findings made by the Board despite conflicting evidence
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected based on presumed state protection
Remedy_Sought: Remand to a different decision-maker for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of Board's decision
Requirement to assess personal risk and country conditions
Decision_Rationale: Board did not adequately justify conclusions on state protection or address personal risk evidence

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant failed to provide sufficient documentation for a 106-day period and had credibility issues
Residency_Compliance: 1,095 days required; applicant was 15 days short
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of procedural unfairness and improper blending of residency tests
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues found by the Citizenship Judge
Relief_Sought: Allowance of appeal and grant of citizenship
Legal_Standard_Applied: Strict application of the Pourghasemi test for residency
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for residency determination; correctness for procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Decision was procedurally fair, no improper blending of tests, and ruling was reasonable
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Judge, Federal Court on appeal

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 183 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant lived in Canada illegally for over 20 years, repeatedly attempted to regularize status, and applied for permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to provide adequate reasons for refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, family ties, hardship upon removal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not properly address relevant evidence of establishment in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-determination of H&C application by a different immigration officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient reasoning provided by Officer despite evidence of long-term residence and hardship
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) Officer

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sought permanent residency based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds after prolonged illegal stay in Canada.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to adequately analyze degree of establishment and hardship
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Duration of residence, family connections, social integration
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not meaningfully engage with evidence supporting establishment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review successful; case remitted for re-determination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new immigration officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Decision lacked sufficient explanation regarding lack of unusual hardship or establishment

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal of H&C application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25(1)
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; matter referred back for re-determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding on credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence of long-term presence and community ties
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 25(1) IRPA – Humanitarian and Compassionate considerations
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship upon removal, deep establishment in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Degree of establishment and adequacy of reasoning in refusal
Crimes.Application_Error: Insufficient analysis and explanation in decision
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of 20+ years of residence, familial and social ties
Crimes.Application_Factor: Length of unauthorized stay, attempts to comply, family hardship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of application to regularize status

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 116 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Reliance on undisclosed risk assessment documents
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Undisclosed risk assessment based on external sources
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure to applicants prior to decision
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of H&C application with procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness under Baker v. Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to provide applicants opportunity to respond to adverse information

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in use of undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Criminal Code
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Risk assessment based on undocumented sources related to tax conviction
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected; landing approval revoked
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Principles of procedural fairness from Baker v. Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Use of undisclosed evidence in decision-making
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Tax evasion conviction and associated risk assessment
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections 4(1)(a), 25(1); Baker duty of fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Immigration Officer relied on internal risk assessment without disclosure
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official record of conviction, undisclosed risk report
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside; remanded for reconsideration

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of state protection and prospective fear
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD's assessment found unreasonable due to factual errors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence on systemic corruption and ineffective enforcement in Mexico
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic abuse and threats from former employer in Mexico
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inadequate state protection despite legal reforms
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider contradictory evidence on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of systemic corruption and lack of enforcement
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution or risk to life
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal risk due to gender-based violence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a new panel

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: History of domestic abuse and ongoing threats
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: No recent direct contact from perpetrator
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of abusive behavior by perpetrator
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threats and history of violence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Targeted due to gender and prior victimization
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and relationship
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, country condition reports, police records
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and consistent with documentary evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible; RPD’s rejection deemed unreasonable

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with protection obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant fled Mexico due to fear of abduction by abusive husband and former employer
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawfully present in Canada during claim
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD failed to address evidence of systemic failures
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient consideration of state protection gaps

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated threats and history of abuse
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Lack of recent incidents cited by RPD
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of coercive and threatening behavior
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – threats of death and bodily harm
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on past relationship and gender
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Chronic abuse and failure of authorities to intervene
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Existence of protective laws in theory
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic lack of protection for women
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – as a woman facing domestic violence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical records, police reports
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and supported by country conditions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible; RPD error in dismissal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in corrupt systems
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD selectively used evidence on anti-corruption efforts
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's account consistent with systemic issues
Crimes.Legal_Rule: State protection must be both available and effective
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Ineffective state response due to corruption
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Reports on corruption in Mexican law enforcement
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection exists due to legal reforms

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of natural justice under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Facts: RPD dismissed claim without proper evaluation of evidence
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: RPD has authority but must act fairly
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD ignored evidence of judicial inefficacy
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to properly assess state protection

Legal_Provision_Violated: section 7 of the Veterans Review and Appeal Board Regulations, SOR/87-601
Governing_Law: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Regulations, SOR/87-601
Application_Facts: Mr. Ladouceur appealed the denial of an increase in his disability pension for post-traumatic arthritis; the Board did not address key medical evidence such as joint pain and stiffness.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide sufficient reasons for decision; violation of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Medical evidence of joint pain and stiffness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to address key medical evidence
Outcome: Board's decision overturned on judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasoned justification requirement under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient reasons provided by the Board; failure to explain dismissal of appeal and address material evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to maintain temporary resident status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA and IRPR - Failure to meet conditions for temporary residency or restoration
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered Canada to care for a sick relative; after her death, they applied for permanent residency and sought restoration of visitor status.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign nationals applying for permanent residency
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to expired status, but applied for restoration
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to consider new temporary purpose for stay
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Evidence of application for permanent residency, intent to remain temporarily during processing
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer ignored evidence of new temporary purpose
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remission for redetermination by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement of temporary purpose under IRPA/IRPR
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer erred by focusing solely on original purpose and not considering ongoing temporary purpose during PR application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with conditions of temporary resident status
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration status and compliance with conditions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer properly assessed the existence of a temporary purpose for stay
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicants provided evidence of pending permanent residency application as basis for continued stay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial of restoration of temporary resident status
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate intent to leave at end of authorized stay
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicants' stated intention to await permanent residency processing
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Intent to apply for permanent residency does not preclude temporary resident status if there is a genuine temporary purpose
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Officer failed to consider updated circumstances and applicable legal provisions
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Pending sponsorship application, duration of processing, original entry purpose
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and IRPR provisions on temporary residence and restoration
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer emphasized original purpose being fulfilled and length of processing time
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of application, affidavits, immigration records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Remission for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18(1) IRPA – Temporary Resident Status; Section 180 IRPR – Restoration of status

Dispute_Type: Administrative dispute over environmental protection obligations
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister erred in failing to identify critical habitat for the Greater Sage-Grouse as required by SARA
Evidence_Assessment: Active leks and nesting/brood-rearing habitats were identifiable using existing models and data
Decision_Outcome: The Minister's decision not to identify critical habitat was unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicants to demonstrate unreasonableness; met
Credibility_Factor: Scientific data and recovery models supporting habitat identification were credible and available
Legal_Rule: Under SARA, the Minister must identify critical habitat 'to the extent possible' based on the best available information
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to comply with statutory duty under SARA to identify critical habitat
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of active leks, nesting and brood-rearing areas, scientific models and habitat data
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation of SARA, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Minister argued that identifying critical habitat was not feasible due to insufficient data
Evidence_Type: Scientific data, ecological models, expert assessments
Remedy_Requested: Redrafting of the critical habitat section in the recovery strategy
Outcome: Judicial review granted; Minister required to redraft critical habitat section within a specified timeframe

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 180(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Myle worked in Canada for four years without a valid work permit
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to address corroborative evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient reasons provided for rejecting credibility
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to properly assess credibility, state protection, and delay issues

Crimes.Crime_Name: Border document misrepresentation (if applicable based on suppressed fragments)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and misrepresentation in refugee proceedings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to provide clear reasons for disbelieving testimony
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic abuse and lack of state protection in St. Vincent
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of analysis of corroborative evidence and country conditions
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess credibility with proper reasoning
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Psychological evidence and country condition reports

Crimes.Crime_Name: Domestic abuse (as described, potentially involving Assault or Criminal Harassment under the Criminal Code)
Crimes.Victim_Status: Female survivor of intimate partner violence
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated abuse, threats to life, lack of police intervention
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Perpetrator had history of abusive behavior
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat to life and safety
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Non-state actor violence with state complicity/omission
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient corroboration through testimony and psychological evaluation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Unduly dismissed by Board without justification
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code (potential assault, criminal harassment), IRPA s. 97(1) (refugee protection)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to apply for refugee protection in a timely manner
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Impact of delay on credibility and eligibility
Crimes.Outcome: Delay deemed excusable due to trauma
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board erred in linking delay to lack of credibility
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of return due to domestic abuse
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Trauma and lack of awareness as mitigating factors
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider trauma-related explanation for delay
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Psychological impact and assistance from Montreal City Mission

Dispute_Type: Alleged infringement of a patented roll-up door design with damage-minimizing features
Legal_Issue: Is Canadian Patent No. 1,178,882 valid, and if so, has the defendant infringed upon it?
Evidence_Assessment: Examination of prior art (Youngs and Nomafa patents), use and sale of Rema Tip Top door, witness testimonies
Decision_Outcome: Patent declared invalid; no infringement found
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff to prove validity and infringement; defendant to challenge validity
Credibility_Factor: Witness testimonies and documentary evidence on prior use and knowledge
Legal_Rule: A registered patent is prima facie valid but can be challenged on grounds of anticipation, obviousness, or failure to meet statutory requirements
Grounds_for_Claim: Sealing engagement and release at a predetermined impact force as distinguishing features
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to invalidity of patent
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art (Youngs, Nomafa), Rema Tip Top door usage and sale, patent claims analysis
Defendant_Response: Challenged patent validity based on anticipation and prior use
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, physical product evidence, expert and factual witness testimony
Remedy_Requested: Damages for patent infringement (by plaintiff); damages for groundless threats (by defendant)
Outcome: Plaintiff's claim dismissed; defendant’s counterclaim for damages dismissed

Legal_Issue: Whether Pfizer's patent is valid and whether Apotex's process infringes the patent claims
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of regulatory approval application
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, prior art, chemical process comparison
Decision_Outcome: Pfizer's patent is valid; Apotex's process infringes
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to prove patent invalidity and non-infringement
Credibility_Factor: Expert witness credibility, scientific evidence reliability
Legal_Rule: A patent is presumed valid unless proven otherwise; infringement occurs if a process uses obvious chemical equivalents
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged prior art invalidating patent, non-infringement due to different process
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim upheld in favor of Pfizer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of unexpected properties of fluconazole, similarity between ACIC Pathway and patented process
Defendant_Response: Challenged patent validity and denied infringement
Evidence_Type: Scientific data, expert testimony, prior patents
Remedy_Requested: Prohibition order to block Apotex's regulatory approval
Outcome: Prohibition order granted; Apotex barred from approval until patent expiry
Legal_Provision: Section 6 of PM(NOC) Regulations, Patent Act provisions on infringement and validity

Crimes.Crime_Name: False or Misleading Information in Citizenship Application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Jreige provided false or misleading information about his absences from Canada
Crimes.Outcome: The discrepancy was not material; error deemed an honest mistake
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Jreige's reporting error considered non-intentional
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residency requirements under the Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Inaccurate reporting of absences in citizenship application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Minor discrepancy (20–25 days) not material to residency requirement
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Truthfulness and accuracy in application disclosures
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Citizenship Judge failed to verify passport evidence of absences
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Requirement to truthfully report absences under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Error alone did not justify overturning approval
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No finding of intentional document fraud

Crimes.Crime_Name: Residency Requirement Non-Compliance under Citizenship Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Jreige absent for 708 days out of required 1,095-day period
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not met due to excessive absences
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable; issue was legal misapplication, not false statements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to properly apply statutory test
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court review of administrative decision
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge discounted importance of physical presence despite clear absence record
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; focus was on legal interpretation
Crimes.Outcome: Citizenship approval set aside due to legal error
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Objective assessment of physical presence under s. 5(1)(c)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by prioritizing family and business ties over statutory physical presence requirement

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution based on religion (Jewish)
Legal_Framework: Convention refugee definition under international and domestic law
Decision_Outcome: Applicants did not meet the burden of proof regarding state protection
Institutional_Action: CRDD reviewed evidence and denied refugee status; judicial review conducted
State_Protection_Assessment: Ukrainian state assessed as able to provide reasonable protection
Risk_Factor: Race, religion, nationality, political opinion, membership in a particular social group
State_Protection_Adequacy: Sufficient state protection exists despite imperfect conditions
Perpetrator_Entity: Non-state actors and possibly state-tolerated anti-Semitic individuals

Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's testimony had inconsistencies and lacked corroboration
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of corroborating evidence
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA relating to refugee protection and judicial review
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility, availability of state protection, internal flight alternative
Application_Error: Inconsistencies in testimony, lack of proof of state protection unavailability
Application_Factor: Credibility, state protection, internal flight alternative

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization involved in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in CLM, which was linked to an attack in Namibia; evidence reasonably supports CLM's involvement in subversion.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: No direct misrepresentation found, but inconsistencies in statements raised concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review conducted based on reasonableness and correctness standards
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Admission of CLM membership, links between CLM and the 1999 attack in Namibia, leadership connection to Mr. Muyongo
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Some inconsistencies in applicant's statements, but not sufficient to undermine decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially credible with noted inconsistencies
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere membership in an organization engaged in subversion by force is sufficient for inadmissibility under s. 34(1)(f)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged error in finding inadmissibility despite lack of direct involvement
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether ID erred in finding Tjiueza inadmissible under s. 34(1)(f) due to inconsistencies and denial of violent involvement
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Concerns due to discrepancies in statements about CLM/CLA identity and activities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, documentary links between CLM and 1999 attack
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Membership in organization deemed to engage in subversion by force
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Admission of CLM membership and conflation of CLM with CLA responsible for attack
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of factual findings and legal interpretation
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of application for relief under s. 34(2)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Membership in organization engaging in subversion by force of a government
Crimes.Violation_Type: Membership in organization involved in subversion by force
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant admitted membership in CLM; ID found reasonable grounds to link CLM to 1999 attack under Mr. Muyongo’s leadership
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in statements led to credibility concerns
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessing factual and legal basis of ID decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Membership admission, organizational links to violent attack, leadership structure
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Minor inconsistencies, but overall evidence deemed sufficient
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially credible – discrepancies noted but did not invalidate conclusion
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Mere membership suffices for inadmissibility if organization engaged in subversion by force

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did Bodine's actions constitute a material misrepresentation under Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Materiality and inducement of error in administration

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Citizenship eligibility due to parent's diplomatic status

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Father's status as Vice-Consul and use of diplomatic passport

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Identity and credibility assessment in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD member erred in assessing identity documents and breached procedural fairness

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; all evidence was considered but not found credible

Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of inconsistent and potentially fraudulent documents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Authenticity of identity documents in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD member erred in assessing document authenticity and credibility

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings due to use of suspicious and unverified documents

Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee protection proceeding and judicial review

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence ignored; RPD evaluated all documents but questioned authenticity
